Posts.Content: Let me say first, I don't know .... Just my thoughts and personal experience. The Urologist I used in Brisbane encouraged me to go on hormone therapy .... After a couple of trials I chose not to. He then talked about "Lead Time Bias" with respect to research into Survival Time with respect to early or late intervention with ADT. He said originally Hormone Theraphy (ADT) was for late stage palliative treatment, and it then became fashionable for early intervention to take place. He said most people would take anything and everything on offer to try and ensure their survival .... He eventually supported my position, as does my current Medical Oncologist. For me personally I'm glad I have done it as I have ...... my current treatment is palliative, but who knows what would have happened if I had done it differently. When I first took ADT in 2010, I was immediately very unwell, physically and emotionally ..... Apart from those few months, I have enjoyed a very good quality of life since diagnosis and treatment in 2010. My choice is to live well as I can for as long as I can .... But I stress this is my choice, and I do the treatment I feel comfortable with ..... but each to their own. Currently doing chemo since June 2014 ... Taxotere ... been a pretty good run so far. There are a lot of variables in these situations .... Our own bodies, our minds .... and how each cancer is different. Regards .... Jim
Posts.Signature: Diagnosed in 2010 54 years. PSA: 05/08/10 8.1 Gleason Score 9 (4+5), cancer in 15 of 18 tissue cores, ductal adenocarcinoma present, peri neural invasion present, extra prostatic extention identified. Stage 3a/b Prostate Cancer. Treatment ADT (Cyproterone) therapy August to November 2010. Nov 2010: HDR Brachytherapy. Dec 2010/Jan 2011: 25 treatments of EBR. PSA readings and Progression: 06/04/11 0.49 (remission) 04/04/12 1.6 09/04/13 6.5 25/03/14 21 June 2014 30 March 2014 Onwards: 1. Bone Scan March 13 T10, Sacrum, Scapula 2. Bone Scan June 14 Left Trochanter, L5, T12, C7, Right side Skull, rib, T9 3 . CT Scan July 14 Extensive nodular tumour within the mesorectal fat which appears to encase the rectum almost circumferentially. There are pathologically enlarged Para-aortic nodes & left iliac nodes. Started Taxotere (Docetaxel) in June 2014 Chemo stabilized bone and reduced soft tissue.
Posts.Title: Thoughts on stopping HT and doing AS

Posts.Content: Thanks for those replies .... Cost is not a problem in Australia as it is approved and on our benefit scheme. I've haven't tolerated the Voladex, Cyproterone (ADT) therapy and have only done 4 months total since 2010. I think my question is will Xtandi or Arbiraterone have the same side effects as standard ADT. I suspect that the knew drugs are the same (I know they work on a cellular level) .... But don't pretend to understand the details. They would appear to be more effective than the older drugs, so my guess is the side effects would also be more pronounced. Still doing Chemo .... But eventually it will fail or my body will have had enough. So my options are limited. For myself all treatment is palliative ...... But that is the same for many. Thanks again for your replies. Regards to all, and best wishes. Not always a fun road .... I don't particularly want to die, but I want to be able to die while I'm still alive .... If you get my drift. It is a balancing act. Jim.

Posts.Title: Xtandi and Zytiga

Posts.Content: Or Enzalutamide and Abiraterone I am currently doing Chemotheraphy (Docetaxel/Taxotere) Started 26 June 2014 ..... weekly treatments, 19 to date with a few breaks. Quite effective and tolerable to date .... but will obviously fail or become intolerable eventually. Multiple bone metastasizes and considerable pelvis invasion ..... prompted into treatment in June by invasion into Bowel and partial blockage. Question: Does anyone have experience with the above drugs? Are the side effects similar to other ADT? Regards, Jim If anyone wants me to expand on my experience with chemo .... please ask.

Posts.Title: Xtandi and Zytiga

Posts.Content: Thanks for your replies ..... Haven't been on site for awhile. In answer to Fairwind .... ADT made me feel weak, depressed, lethargic etc. Friend of mine did ADT for 18 months, and maybe this influenced me. It could be said I paid the price for not doing ADT .... But I've had a good life since 2010. Maybe my intolerance was emotional and mental, as much as physical. Still doing weekly Taxotere .... Wednesday will be 28 treatments, having missed a few weeks since late June 2014 ..... Currently having the first week of each month off. Xtandi etc still an option .... Not sure if I updated, but in June 2014 had about 12 bone metastises, and a tumours bowel and rectum. Chemo has reduced soft tissue tumours and stabilised bone. Oncologist said before I started .... 33% get a reduction .... 33% get stability .... And 33% it fails. I fortunately was in the top one third for effect .... And also very lucky that the side effects to date have been very bearable. Thanks for posting everyone. Regards, Jim

Posts.Title: Xtandi and Zytiga

Posts.Content: I liked the desert analogy .... says it all really. Also like the bit about Doctors trying ADT before passing comment about how intrusive it may or may not be .... for me it was devastating. Early or late intervention .... As Kris Kristoferson sings ..... "So many questions .. So many answers .. So many reasons ... Most of them wrong" We are left with our own decisions .... It was suggested to me doing a Pelvic Extenteration .... Even though the bone cancer would have been a negative. I know someone who has had it done, and I genuinely say he is a better man than me .... We have to know our limitations. Same with ADT .... Each to his own. I feel like I am wandering lost in the desert .... maybe we all are. We can still try to be happy a lot of the time .... If our lives are limited, our time is precious.

Posts.Title: Xtandi and Zytiga

Posts.Content: Well I didn't do the Hormone Theraphy, and I don't regret it. Can't say I've had a successful outcome, but that was always on the cards. I did try ADT and it turned my life to hell. I've had nearly 5 years of full life since 2010. Whatever your husband wants to do, in my opinion you should let him do it. Having cancer doesn't mean you have to hand over control of your life to anyone. A Colerectal Surgeon said to me the other day that he doesn't have PSA test .... He said he would rather live 6 months potent than 6 years impotent .... He also said, using a horse riding analogy, to stay in the saddle .... That is stay in control. I'm not saying he is right or wrong .... Just saying it is a decision for the individual. It's not just about sex .... It is about emotions, about physical strength, well being, bone strength etc. I wish you both well.

CT Scan July 14 Extensive nodular tumour within the mesorectal fat which appears to encase the rectum almost circumferentially. There are pathologically enlarged Para-aortic nodes & left iliac nodes. Started Taxotere (Docetaxel) in June 2014 Chemo stabilized bone and reduced soft tissue.
Posts.Title: Opting out of Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: Well I didn't do the Hormone Theraphy, and I don't regret it. Can't say I've had a successful outcome, but that was always on the cards. I did try ADT and it turned my life to hell. I've had nearly 5 years of full life since 2010. Whatever your husband wants to do, in my opinion you should let him do it. Having cancer doesn't mean you have to hand over control of your life to anyone. A Colerectal Surgeon said to me the other day that he doesn't have PSA test .... He said he would rather live 6 months potent than 6 years impotent .... He also said, using a horse riding analogy, to stay in the saddle .... That is stay in control. I'm not saying he is right or wrong .... Just saying it is a decision for the individual. It's not just about sex .... It is about emotions, about physical strength, well being, bone strength etc. I wish you both well.

Posts.Title: Opting out of Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: Gday Peggysson, I understand your despair. My sexual rehabilitation and recovery from erectile dysfunction has been one hell of a journey for me, and I did it all with the help of a very caring and understanding doctor here in Brisbane. Michael Gillman is a good man. I am also blessed with a wonderful caring, considerate and understanding wife. Still with both of these fine souls in my corner it was a very confronting and emotional journey. Before treatment and during ADT, I started on 5 mg Cialis daily. Post treatment I was physically messed up a fair bit. The HDR Brachytherapy caused complete numbness to the whole genital area, from memory it lasted a couple of months. I mean complete as in when you have an injection at the dentist. Also suffered Climacturia for a while .also very confronting. Tried tablets post radiation, but daily Cialis started causing muscle pains, and other single tablets sometimes worked, but with a lot of performance anxiety. Now mainly use Alprostadil injections, and after much ado they are now effective and simple to use. The Sloane Kettering site has good articles on all this. Rightly or wrongly I put quality of life ahead of survival, and I still do. I can fairly confidently say I will die from this cancer, and if it is the case my life is somewhat shortened, I want to live it as well and enthusiastically as I can. So just for today, that is what I am doing. My sexual function continues to get better as time goes on, which is a direct contradiction to what is supposed to happen post radiation. My cancer prognosis would appear to deteriorate as time goes on, but we will deal with that as time progresses. There is a solution to erectile function  our cancer is another story. So hang in there . And we must try to live well. The more our lives are shortened, the more valuable our time becomes. Regards, Jim I hope I havent double posted .. one got lost along the way.

Posts.Title: 2 years after surgery. single and the effects of surgery related impotence

Posts.Content: Thanks to all who read and replied. Snuffy Myers and his practices are well know here in Brisbane. Their is a very active support group here and the internet makes all other accessible. http://www.prostate.org.au/articleLi...Support-Groups I know of one person here that has been over to Snufffy Myers within the last 2 months. My wife and I have researched a lot over the last 3 years, with Sloane Kettering being a wonderful site. October will be a crunch time for me, although the Urologist might be prepared to let me scratch through to April 2014 .... seem it is debatable as to the advantages/disadvantages of early or late intervention. I admit I am having a lot of trouble getting my mind around it .... Below is an interesting article which appeared yesterday. I would be much more likely to try something experimental which may or may not work .... than to submit to existing ADT therapy. But I have to keep an open mind. I am here to listen and learn, so I will try my best. Regards Jim. http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-07-2...humans/4851234
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Cranberry capsules. Ural. Both worked pretty well for me, and are recommended for Cystitis. 3 years later I still regularly take Cranbrerry, and sometimes Ural. Nothing is a cure in this game, but it helps a lot with symptoms. I tried the tablets prescribed by Oncologist but they actually made symptom worse. I think using the likes of daily Cialis also helps, as it improves the blood flow to the area and could reduce scaring. Maybe Zinc also? Regards Jim

Posts.Title: Hi All Flomax Question

Posts.Content: History from August 2010, aged 54 years. After Blood Tests, MRI, Transrectal biopsy, cystoscopy, bone scan etc. Diagnosis: PSA: 050810: 8.1 Gleason Score 9 (4+5), with cancer in 15 of the 18 tissue cores, ductal adenocarcinoma present, peri neural invasion present, extra prostatic extention identified. Prostate volume was 71cc. Stage 3a/b Prostate Cancer (second opinion) Seminal vesicles, lymph nodes and bone scan clear. I was advised that surgery would not be a good idea, as there would be positive margins, and the risk of incontinence, and impotence almost 100%. I said I would prefer Quality of life over quantity. Started hormone (Cyproterone ... 100 to 300 mg daily) therapy August to November 2010 After 3 months Hormone Therapy, into hospital for 3 days HDR Brachytherapy (Nov 2010), then 25 treatments of External Beam Radiation (Dec 2010/January 2011) . 66.25 Gy (or 83 Gy, some confusion) of Radiation, (20.25 Gy HDR brachytherapy and 46 Gy EBR) Subsequent PSA readings: 060411: 0.49 (Oncologist said I was in remission) 250811: 0.63 061011: 0.75 (6 month *1.5) 040412: 1.6 (6 month *2.1 .. 12 month * 3.25) 191012: 2.7 (6 month * 1.68 .. 12 month * 3.60) .. Urologist said it appear the cancer has metastasized. 090413: 6.5 (6 month *2.4 .. 12 month *4)  both urologist and Oncologist said it is indicative of Metastatic prostate cancer) Due for another PSA in October 2013, and as of April 2013, Bone Scans and MRI are clear. I have resisted hormone therapy, expect for the original 3 months, which was to reduce size of prostate to avoid damage to surround organs. I sort help from alternate therapies in conjunction with the medical approach, taking Selenium, zinc, Pawpaw leaf extract, Cranberry, Chromium, Bio-Curcumin, Lipoec etc. Recently in desperation, after 4 successive 6 monthly rises in PSA, and doubling time currently just over 4 months, I have started taking Baking Soda/Maple Syrup mix. I am no great believer in alternate therapy, but the medical approach from here on does not excite me much either. I am currently in good health. Some bladder irritation, but Bladder and Bowel not a problem, and sexual function fine. Sometime use Cialis or Alprostadil injections. Live on a farm and still work well, ride horses etc. A long an overly detailed post I know, but no point in telling half the story. Don't know if it is helpful to anyone, but I am open to any suggestions. Feel free to shift this post to the appropriate thread. I am getting a little lost on the site. Regards, Jim
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: I started docetaxel in June 2014. My only suggestion would be to try to get your oncologist to do it weekly, because a third of the dose weekly, seems much more tolerable than the full dose every 3 weeks. Currently I have the first week of each month off, and have treatment every Wednesday. 30 treatments since June 2014 and still going .... My signature has my history. Very effective to date, side effects quite bearable .... Have a farm, still work at a steady pace .... Sometime quite steady, but I have ridden a couple of horses this morn and a few other chores. Anything else I can say please ask ...I am an open book, so would be delighted to answer any questions. All the best. Jim

Posts.Title: .....Chemo time!

Posts.Content: I agree .... and each person will react differently anyway, as you say. The oncologist tells me the treatment I am on is palliative, purely for symptom control, so most probably stage 4 .... not sure what the M1a and M1b stand for. Some different terms used between Australia and USA. Still think weekly is a good option if you can get it .... I wouldn't under estimate the side effects, but just trying to give you hope that it may be better than you think. Last June a palliative care Doctor, the General Practitioner, and the Oncologist all told me I should measure my life span in months, not years (because of the pelvic invasion), but because of the success of treatment to date, that has not been the case ... At least to this stage anyway. I'm no Doctor, simply the patient .... I think from talking to others in Day Oncology, that Docetaxel (Taxotere) is also used for women with breast cancer, and from my observation the side effects of the 3 weekly dose can be quite severe. Anyway I wish you both well.
